subsection.title: Preliminaries: Line, Plane, Space, Etc.
subsection.p:
Questions:
State whether the following are true or false. If false, give a counterexample/reason, and if true, explain why it is true.
A system of 5 linear equations can have 5 solutions.
The solution set to any consistent system of linear equations is a subspace.
The solution set to a consistent system of linear equations of the form Ax=0 is a subspace.
The intersection of any two subspaces (i.e., the collection of points that are in both subspaces) is a subspace.
The union of any two subspaces (i.e., the collection of points that are in at least on of the subspaces) is a subspace.

Answers:
False. The solution set to any system of linear equations is either empty (inconsistent equations), has a unique solution (consistent equations, no free variables), or infinite (if there is a free variable, since this free variable can then take on the value of any of the infinitely many real numbers).
False. For example, the solution set of the set of equations x+y=3 in \mathbb R^2 is a line, but doesn't pass through the origin.
True. Here, we can check the axioms in the definition of a subspace. Given the shape of the equation Ax=0, we clearly have that the zero vector solves this equation, and so the solution set contains the origin (which solves the problem encountered in the last example). Now, suppose that x and y are solutions. Then A(x+y)=Ax+Ay=0+0=0, and so x+y also solves the system, and for a real number \alpha, A(\alpha x)=\alpha Ax=\alpha0=0, and so \alpha x is a solution too. Thus, the solution set satisfies parts 2 and 3 of the definition of a subspace, and hence is a subspace.
True. Suppose that V and W are both subspaces of \mathbb R^n. Then we can check each part of the definition is satisfied by the intersection of V and W. Firstly, since 0 is in both subspaces, its in the intersection, so it is a nonempty set. Furthermore, if x and y are in the intersection and \alpha is a real number, then \alpha x+y is in the intersection, using the axioms in the definition of subspace applied twice, once using the fact that x and y are in particular both in V, and once using that they are both in W. Note that this implies both the second and third parts of the definition of subspace, as we can take \alpha=1 for part 2 of the definition, and choose y=0 for part 3 of the definition.
False. Although the union of two intersections always contained the origin, it will usually not be a subspace. For instance, consider the two lines y=\pm x in \mathbb R^2. Their union is not closed under addition. To see this, we just need a counter example. For instance, choose (1,-1) on the line y=-x and the point (2,2) on the line y=x. In particular, both of these points are on the union of these two lines (which looks like an "X" in the plane). However, the sum of these two points, (1,-1)+(2,2)=(3,-1), is not on the union of the two lines, as 3\neq\pm(-1).
